title: hey teacher leave kids lunch
story: NewsopinionHey, teacher! Leave that kid's lunch aloneTyrant teachers checking every child's lunch is school dinner madnessShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByFleet Street FoxColumnist12:37, 19 SEP 2018Updated13:39, 19 SEP 2018Newsopinion"Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailYellow belly custard, green snot pie. Mix it all together with a dead dog's eye. Slap it in a bucket nice an' thick, and wash it all down with a cup of cold sick. So ran one of the politer songs in the playground at my school, back in the days when there was actually money to spend on giving every primary-age pupil a hot meal at lunchtime. The best that could be said of the food we were subjected to was that it was hot. Otherwise, it was vegetables with the goodness boiled out of them, meat sliced so thinly it looked ill, and strange experiments involving batter.  The bowl of fresh fruit was dusted off optimistically each day by the dinner ladies and studiously ignored by everyone, and the lucky kids were the ones with a She-Ra lunchbox and a cheese sandwich made by their mum.  The only dish I ever went back for seconds of was slabs of chocolate sponge, baked in an enormous 2ft tray, slathered in mint-flavoured green custard. I'd kill for a bowl of that even today.  Nowadays there are very few kitchen staff, zero dinner ladies patrolling to make sure you've emptied your plate, and no basic training in negotiating skills enabling you to trade your peas for someone else's carrots. There's just tyranny. Tyranny always begins reasonably. So it was that Turkey Twizzlers were rightly discovered to be an atrocity against the digestive system, and Jamie Oliver campaigned for a school dining revolution. But those good intentions led to guidelines, and idiots interpreted them as rules, and no-one is allowed to question the not-rules for fear of being denounced as a Bad Parent.  Which gets us to the point where a child whose mum takes so much care over the lunchbox that she turns cucumber slices into tiny little flowers is told that it was too unhealthy.   Now, I'd agree with that statement. I'd say cutting the crusts off the sandwiches is unhealthy, asking anyone to eat celery without humous is inhuman, and as cucumbers are 96% water they're a waste of chewing. But the teacher in this case took the view that the three mini cookies in the top right corner were a dietary abomination, forbid the child from eating them, and sent them home with a note for mother.  Never mind that perhaps the parent included them as a treat to make up for the fun-free meal. Never mind that the ingredients of cookies - flour, butter, sugar - are the main constituents of most human food and in a balanced diet of no concern at all. And never mind that chocolate is considered a superfood.  To that teacher, cookies were a Turkey Twizzler in disguise, and kids that eat treats must be saved from their parents.  Of course there are parents who send their children to school with a packet of Quavers and a Coke. And of course those children are going to be disruptive, hyperactive, and ill  it carries on for too long. When that happens the sensible course of action is to find out why. Are the parents dead? Are they asleep? Have they run out of money and giving the child whatever they can nick from a pub? Perhaps the child has severe autism and vomits  asked to eat something else.  If a child is obese, they're chugging most of their calories at home. Any child with an atrocious diet probably has other problems, and banning them from eating the one thing they can or will eat is not going to solve the underlying issue.  It just tells parents, and pupils, that teachers get it wrong, and must be gone around. So they hide it, lie, or avoid education altogether.   Tyranny grows when it doesn't know where to stop. And so there are schools where a teacher bans cheese because it is mostly fat, and ignores the fact it's good fat and comes along with calcium. There are schools were lettuce is encouraged but not checked to see  it was washed, and where a potato is considered starchy, rather than a source of fibre and energy.   Any child's lunch box can be decimated by the application of stupidity and a food fad. The truth is every cell in your body only metabolises because there is some sort of sugar in your diet, and there is a dference between refined and unrefined, fructose and glucose. Unless you are in the 1% of the population with coeliac disease there's no harm at all in gluten, you can't move a muscle without carbohydrate as fuel, and a diet high in fats can reduce a child's risk of seizures.  The latest studies show children's yoghurts have lots of sugar. Well, broccoli has a fair bit of sugar too, and zero Vitamin D. Under the teacher tyranny, both should be banned. Most parents grew up in a world filled with toad-in-the-hole, vegetable splodge and green custard, and most of us are not obese, sick or dead. Some of us used to eat dirt, or in my case sugar lumps by the handful. I still have my own teeth and a waistline. It must be something other than celery, or a lack thereof, which is causing the problem of malnourished children.  We live in a world where teachers are asked to police. Where parents are required to parent in ways no parent has ever done before, children are infantilised all the way through university and there's a new food fad every 5 minutes claiming to fix all your problems. We don't live in a world where we are encouraged to find out  something is true. We're just asked to believe. So we rail against processed food, and forget that every single thing which isn't covered in dirt has been processed. Milk is pasteurised, flour is ground, corn is hulled. We buy vegetables from supermarkets where they're waxed, gassed, and given chemical washes. We hope the sausages are pork, we don't ask why the bread lasts so long and we're told that pizzas will kill our whole families.  The Italians eat pizza but live for a long time. But perhaps that's because they make the pizzas, using flour and oil and eggs, mush the tomatoes to make passata and scatter whatever is in the fridge as a topping.  So tell me this. If I make sandwiches using chicken saved from the Sunday roast, jam I made myself without preservatives, and add some raisins and a home-made fairy cake with raspberries from the garden, how much of it would a teacher let my daughter eat?

title: home truths theresa housing mirror
story: NewsopinionSome home truths for Theresa May on housing: Mirror Politics morning briefingThe Prime Minister will today position herself as the champion of social housing. Her record tells a dferent storyShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByJason BeattieHead of politics08:51, 19 SEP 2018NewsopinionTheresa May and her husband Philip at Chequers, which is a form of social housing "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email Theresa May will today make another effort to remind people she has not totally forgotten the domestic agenda with a speech on housing.   The Prime Minister will tell the National Housing Federation conference that “our friends and neighbours who live in social housing are not second-rate citizens.”   Leaving aside how many of her friends and neighbours in her wealthy Berkshire village actually live in social housing, Mrs May’s speech is a bit rich from someone who voted against making rented homes fit for human habitation, imposed the bedroom tax, put up council taxes for council tenants, introduced market rates for council house tenants, forced housing associations to sell off properties and continues to break the promise for like-for-like replacements for every council house sold .        Then there is the Tory obsession with right-to-buy which helped promulgate the stigma of council housing while leaving many families unable to live in the community in which they were brought up.   And there is the help-to-buy scheme which primarily benefited those on middle incomes and fuelled housing demand when the focus should have been on supply.   Just as with her just about managing speech on the steps of Downing Street, the Prime Minister identies the problem but is blinkered to the damage caused by her own policies.   Mrs May is promising housing associations an additional &pound2billion in funding but it is not clear where the money is coming from  or over what time period it will be delivered.

title: right wingers publicly plot opening
story: NewsRight-wingers publicly plot opening up the NHS to US firms after BrexitThe plans are included in a 239-page report by the Initiative for Free Trade - a think tank backed by hard Brexiteers and launched by Boris Johnson in the Foreign OfficeShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByDan BloomOnline Political Editor16:14, 19 SEP 2018Updated16:19, 19 SEP 2018NewsTheresa May has insisted the NHS is not for sale - but what about right-wingers with links to Tories? "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailRight-wingers have been slammed after publicly plotting to open up the NHS to competition from US firms after Brexit. The idea is included in a 239-page report by the Initiative for Free Trade - a think tank backed by hard Brexiteers and launched by Boris Johnson in the Foreign Office map room. Spelling out an 'ideal' trade deal between the US and UK, the report says there should be zero restrictions on competition for government procurement. An executive summary of the report explains: Health services are an area where both sides would benefit from openness to foreign competition, although we recognize any changes to existing regulations will be extremely controversial. Perhaps, then, for other areas the initial focus should be on other fields such as education or legal services, where negotiators can test the waters and see what is possible.  That said, we would envisage a swt, time-tabled implementation of recognition across all areas within 5 years. It adds import restrictions that are based on unsubstantiated public health and safety concerns should be dropped - leading to fears chlorine-washed chicken could be imported.  Labour MP Peter Kyle, of the anti- Brexit People’s Vote campaign, said: “This is the real agenda of the Brexit elite, in black and white.  They want to use Brexit as an excuse to slash and burn the protections and standards we value so highly, and to chop up and sell off our NHS to the highest bidder. The report also recommends free movement of workers between the UK and the US,  they have a confirmed job to go to. The IFT was launched last year as the Institute for Free Trade, but dropped 'institute' from its name after a dispute with Companies House.

title: second referendum brexit could happen
story: NewsSecond referendum on Brexit COULD happen admits Tory minister in surprisingly candid interviewMel Stride blurted out the prediction that MPs could trigger a new public vote  they reject Theresa May's 'Chequers' plan for BrexitShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByDan BloomOnline Political Editor14:14, 19 SEP 2018Updated14:56, 19 SEP 2018Newsthis.style.display='none'"/Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror/news/politics/video/tory-minister-on-second-referendum-13273463,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-M3TH25P,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,bundledCss:false,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx/rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail/F/QVgi9PbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_/,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,bundledCss:false,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx/rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail/F/QVgi9PbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_/,nativeAppBanner:true""Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA second referendum on Brexit could happen within months, a Tory minister suggested today in a surprisingly candid interview.  Mel Stride blurted out the prediction that MPs could trigger a new public vote  they reject Theresa May's 'Chequers' plan for Brexit .  The Treasury minister told Sky News: Those to the right of the party - the pro-Brexit wing - will be very concerned that  that deal doesn't prevail, they'll end up in the situation where we could have a second referendum and we could end up not leaving the EU altogether. So there is a danger of that happening  Chequers doesn't prevail. It's a sharp departure from the words of his boss Theresa May - who has bluntly claimed there isn't going to be another vote. Mrs May's plan faces a make-or-break vote in Parliament in about two months' time, after it is finalised in negotiations between Britain and the EU.  The prospect of defeat is looking more likely for Mrs May after Labour signalled it would try and defeat her plan. Losing the vote would hurl Brexit into unprecedented crisis and could trigger a leadership contest or general election. Mr Stride was trying to explain how he thinks Brexiteer Tories will fall in line behind the PM - despite threats that 80, including ex-Brexit Secretary David Davis, will vote against Chequers.  But his words come just hours after second referendum campaigners published a blueprint on how it can take place well before Brexit Day in March 2019.  Lord Kerr, the peer who wrote Article 50 , said the UK's notice to leave can still be withdrawn and there would be no dficulty rewriting the timetable.    Mr Stride's comments were seized upon by campaigners for a second referendum - who include backbench MPs from all parties and London mayor Sadiq Khan .  Labour MP Tulip Siddiq, of the Best For Britain group, said: After weeks of denying the obvious, a senior minister has let the cat out of the bag. The government know that  their deal is voted down the only way out of this mess is a people's vote. Mel Stride is the first minister to admit a fresh referendum is possible and it is now clear that the public deserve a final say on the Brexit deal. Labour MP Alison McGovern, of the People’s Vote campaign, said: This has changed everything. A minister has had the courage to tell the truth about the mess the Government are in over Brexit. The UK's current Brexit plan is based on a deal Theresa May drew up at Chequers, her country retreat, in July 2018. At the time it was seen as a major sht to soft Brexit - prompting hard-Leaver Cabinet ministers David Davis and Boris Johnson to resign. The 'Facilitated Customs Arrangement' is a bid to solve the biggest problem of Brexit - how to stop a hard border between Northern Ireland and either the EU, or the rest of the UK. It would keep the UK closely aligned with the EU in a new free trade area for goods. Under this plan, the UK would share a common rulebook with Brussels for goods, including agricultural and food products. Britain would also collect some, but not all, customs tarfs on the EU's behalf. Parliament would technically keep the right to block future rules. But Tory Brexiteers said this olive branch would useless in practice. They forced Theresa May to amend the plan to say the EU should collects tarfs on the UK's behalf. Mrs May insisted this didn't scupper her plan. But EU chief negotiator Michel Barnier disagreed, and has continued to suggest there will be a border between Northern Ireland and the rest of the UK. Remainers and Labour have also opposed the Chequers plan, saying it leaves Britain half-in-half-out of the EU in the worst of all worlds.  With a November deadline to agree a deal with the EU looming, and the plan facing a vote in Parliament after that, the UK is now ramping up plans to leave in March 2019 with no deal.

title: filming north korea great no
story: News'Filming in North Korea was great, no one had heard of Monty Python and thought I was just some old bloke', says Michael PalinAround the world he is famous for being a member of the surreal comedy team Monty Python and his TV travelogues but when Michael Palin went to film in North Korea no-one had any idea who he wasShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByMark JefferiesShowbiz Editor12:08, 19 SEP 2018Newsthis.style.display='none'"/Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror/tv/video/michael-palin-journeys-north-korea-13264794,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-M3TH25P,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,bundledCss:false,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx/rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail/F/QVgi9PbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_/,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,bundledCss:false,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx/rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail/F/QVgi9PbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_/,nativeAppBanner:true""Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailMichael Palin had only been in North Korea for a few hours when he was woken suddenly by an unusual sound. Already nervous about what lay ahead, he heard what he describes as “the worlds most unusual wake up call” - the entire city of Pyongyang drowned in a piece of music called 'Where Are You Dear General?' loudly repeated throughout the streets at regular intervals from the crack of dawn. “I first heard this at five o'clock and it is like music that emanates from the whole city,” he explains. “It was eerie music which was quite menacing at five o'clock and then became rather strange and you couldn't tell where it was coming from.  “It sounds vaguely Brian Eno. It’s not like music blaring and you would immediately say that is propaganda music. I did honestly think that something had gone in my head or a terrible dream I was going through. “Other cities you think of screaming sirens but there is none of that at all. This noise, you couldn't avoid it.” Palin, 75, was given two weeks to film the first in-depth Western documentary for many years about the country that is shrouded in secrecy. The country is famous for its missiles and propaganda, which explains why Michael says his we “uncharacteristically didn't want me to do this” but he was too intrigued to turn it down. Now safely back in England, Palin describes the trip as “the most revealing journey of my le”. And the surprises begin even before he sets foot in the North Korea as the TV screens on the train ride from South Korea across the bridge to get to his final destination show films of missiles and a smiling Kim Jong-un. From then on, everywhere he looked things were noticeably dferent from the western world. “There is no advertising and there is just one advert for a car that was built with South Korean support but apart from that everything else is propaganda,” Michael explains.  “So we had 14 days without Coca-cola, chewing gum, washing powder etc. “If you are at home in North Korea apart from in the lavatory and in the kitchen. There are pictures of the leaders everywhere and everyone has to wear a picture of the leader on their unorm unless they are at work. So it is absolutely total the omnipotent gaze of the leaders. But interesting enough  you are North Korean, and it has been going since 1945, they tend to ignore them. It is more provocative to you then it is to a North Korean.” Palin's trips to places like the North Pole and Himalayas have been seen by millions of viewers over the years around the globe. But unlike any of his other travelogues he has made over the years there were many restrictions in North Korea, which saw him accompanied everywhere by two guides Soo Yang and Chang Chu who talk to him on camera but also keep a watchful eye on what is being filmed. “The first day was a very tricky day,” admits Michael. “Because we were in front of the monuments of the two great leaders and there are ious rules there and the leaders have to be filmed in their entirety and so you have to stand a long way back so you can film the full  of them. Also there were ious ways that you had to behave and I did my first piece to camera and I was quite pleased and I thought, well I have said what I want to say and that is quite good and I look around and they  never directly confronted me but Neil our director came over for a chat and I said to Neil, 'did I say something wrong? What did I say? Did I mention something about the regime?. “And in the end they said no, no, no, You have got to do it again because you had your hand in your pocket and that is disrespectful, so that was interesting.” Palin's two part documentary begins with him taking a train from South Korea into the Northern country and the contrast between the high rise building and advertising billboards in the South and the stark space and propaganda posters in the North are as clear. But Palin insists he has gone “beyond the politics” and does get to speak and interact with some of the 25 million population. At a May Day celebration in the city of Moranbong hundreds of men and women are seen dancing and drinking rice wine in a park in the city centre.  One local even puts a garland made of green foliage on Michael's head. He said: There was no way that our minders could control everything that we saw and nor did they really try to. They were nearby by they let us film everything that was going on on that hill and next to the amusements and the parks on that particular day and I almost feel when you are filming a country, it’s not really the big statements or the big policies that you are hearing about that make the dference. To me, it’s the way that people move and the way people talk and the way that people eat. Decades of a rigid state-controlled system have led to stagnation and a leadership dependent on the cult of personality as well as isolation from the rest of the world. But despite this negative image, Palin said: “North Korea wasn’t what I expected and I had been conditioned by a general idea that this is a dark place. A grim place of repression and lack of freedom and I think when we were going there, I felt that this was going to somehow be reflected in the look of the place and the way that people behaved towards to me, but that just didn't happen. “I enjoyed finding out it wasn't a dreadfully threatening place and I enjoyed making friends with people and understand what it was all about. “Our stern minders weren't that stern in the end. I had my 75th birthday whilst I was there and at the end of the day they bought me with a birthday cake and a special party.  This huge birthday cake must have used up their agricultural output. I felt more relaxed as time went on I did at one time thing I would be fearful or lonely but I didn't feel that. “We talked a lot together and evaluated the day and I think we all had this feeling at the end that we didn't particularly want to leave. That was not just me that was all the crew. It had been embedded in me before I went out there that six days would be enough and I was going for two weeks. “I know we have been looked after very well and better than a lot of people in the country but there was this feeling that it hadn't been the monster and it was actually quite serene. “There were no traffic jams so it was nice to walk, no advertising which was quite odd, all they are selling really is the people united behind the leaders and even that isn't as heavy as I thought it would be. So my feeling was relief tempered with happiness.”

title: muller light addict who eats
story: NewsMuller Light addict who eats up to 24 yogurts a day "devastated" after Slimming World changes Syn valueNikki regularly eats between six and eight pots a day - but can get through four six-packs "on a bad day"Share&nbsp&nbspCommentsByNicola OakleyHead of Audience15:14, 19 SEP 2018NewsNikki has lost almost three stone on Slimming World despite getting through an alarming number of yogurts a day "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email A Slimming World member who eats up to 24 Muller Lights a day has been left devastated after the weight loss organisation increased the yogurts' 'Syn' value .  Mum-of-four Nikki O'Neill, 46, from Bournemouth, says she became addicted to the low-fat snacks - which were previously 'free' to eat on the diet plan - as they satisfied her sweet tooth. She munches her way through six or eight yogurts daily, but says on a bad day she can consume three or four multipacks. Slimming World announced on Monday that Muller Lights now have to be counted as 1 'Syn' each, within a member's daily allowance of between five and 15.  If Nikki continued to eat her way through multipacks, she would now far exceed her maximum Syn allowance before counting any other treats. A plain vanilla Muller Light contains 99 calories per pot, meaning 24 would add up to an intake of 2376 calories in yogurts alone. Despite her addiction, Nikki, who works in a school as a kitchen assistant, has managed to lose a huge amount of weight on the plan.  She told : I'm devastated by the news. I've been doing Slimming World for five and a half months and I've lost almost three stone. I never liked yogurts until I joined. I have a sweet tooth so I soon realised that this would be a great replacement for sugary snacks. Most people on Slimming World might have one or two low fat yogurts a day, but Nikki confesses she eats between six and eight Muller Lights daily. On a bad day I could easily get through three or four six-packs, she said. That adds up to between 18 and 24 yogurts in as many hours.  Nikki explained: I would usually have two for breakfast mixed in with oats, then a couple for lunch and dinner. The rest are in between meals - probably every half an hour when I am home in between my jobs. I have the fruit flavours in the morning and during the day. Then in the evening I love the orange or caramel ones with added chocolate bits. I'm gutted, though, as they have just brought out banoffee flavour and I would have lived off these!  Nikki estimates she spends upwards of &pound30 per week on the light desserts - and she panics  she doesn't have any in the fridge. Every night, pretty much, my husband will ask  we need anything from the shops and yogurts are always on the list, she said. The school worker is mum to Luke, nine, Holly, 10, Jack, 13 and 28-year-old Liam and says she is renowned for her addiction among her friends and family - who think it's hilarious. I was gutted when I heard they were to have Syns but I also found it so funny that friends and family tagged me in posts about it, she said.  I genuinely worry what I will have as my go-to sweet snack now. It's going to be a really hard habit to break, that's for sure. I will have to savour each one instead of having four or five in a row! When asked  she's tempted to carry on eating the yogurts excessively, given how much weight she's lost, Nikki had a logical answer. To be honest,  I cut down to, say, six a day, that will probably make a big dference to my weight loss. A Slimming World spokesperson said: “We routinely review our guidance for all food products to ensure it includes the most up to date information and advice, and incorporates feedback from our members and Consultants.

title: eight week old puppy found
story: NewsEight-week-old puppy found dumped with paws tied together in handbag dangling from charity shop doorThe tiny pup was abandoned alongside a note which read 'found this puppy'Share&nbsp&nbspCommentsByNicola OakleyHead of Audience13:16, 19 SEP 2018Updated13:21, 19 SEP 2018NewsTiny Radley was discovered in the charity shop "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailAn eight-week-old puppy is lucky to be alive after he was found with his paws tied together in a handbag dangling from a charity shop door. Radley, thought to be a border terrier cross, was found by a member of the public in the early hours of Monday morning in west London. The stressed and frightened pup was discovered with an elasticated hairband tied around his legs which was cutting off his circulation and damaging his paws. There was also an unopened tin of dog food in the handbag, which had a note stuck on the outside that said: Found this puppy.  Radley is said to be in fairly good body condition but has had diarrhoea so he is being closely monitored. The RSPCA's Inspector Phil Norman is now investigating how the pooch came to be dumped in the handbag. He said: We received a call from a woman who’d found a little puppy in a red handbag fastened to the door handle of a charity shop in The Broadway, Greenford. “It was around 2am on Monday morning. “Poor little Radley must have been very stressed and frightened being stuffed into that handbag and abandoned in the middle of the night.  The pup was taken to the RSPCA's Putney Animal Hospital, in south-west London. Inspector Norman has spoken to the local shops and is gathering CCTV in order to trace whoever is responsible for abandoning the pup. He’s also seeking any witnesses who may have seen anything suspicious in the area at the time or who recognise Radley to get in touch by calling the charity’s appeal line on 0300 123 8018. London veterinary director Caroline Allen said: “As this little pup was found in a handbag we decided to name him Radley - and he’s now winning over the hearts of all of the staff here!

story: NewsExperts debunk top myths around frozen food which Brits believe to be trueResearchers who carried out a detailed study found one fth of consumers wrongly believe frozen fruits and vegetables contain fewer nutrients than their fresh counterpartsShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByAstrid Hall15:57, 19 SEP 2018Updated17:05, 19 SEP 2018Newsthis.style.display='none'"/Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror/news/uk-news/video/birdseye-myths-frozen-food-13274653,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-M3TH25P,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,bundledCss:false,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx/rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail/F/QVgi9PbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_/,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,bundledCss:false,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx/rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail/F/QVgi9PbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_/,nativeAppBanner:true""Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailExperts have debunked a series of myths around frozen food which millions of Brits believe to be true. Researchers who carried out a detailed study found one fth of consumers wrongly believe frozen fruits and vegetables contain fewer nutrients than their fresh counterparts. Another one in 12 mistakenly think frozen food doesn’t last as long as a fresh product while another one in ten reckon frozen food is more expensive. And two fths are of the opinion frozen foods are filled with preservatives to give them a longer shelf-le. Others myths surrounding frozen meals are that you can't safely cook them from frozen, with four in 10 believing you aren’t supposed to heat food from frozen.  Following a study of 2,000 adults by Birds Eye, dietitian and health writer, Laura Tilt said: “Many, but not all, foods can be cooked from frozen. ''Examples include chicken breasts, mince, pizza, fruit and vegetables, fish and ready meals. “The best advice is to check the packet of the food for specic cooking and heating instructions.” The study also found nearly two thirds don’t think that all types of food can be frozen, but experts revealed the opposite is true. The truth is that only a few foods aren’t ideal for freezing, such as eggs, both raw and cooked, or vegetables with a high water content as they tend to go mushy upon defrosting. Around one in four believe you can refreeze food once it's thawed without cooking it first, which is also false because you can refreeze it but must cook between thawing and refreezing.  Furthermore, 12 per cent weren't aware frozen food can be part of a health diet. Others - 38 per cent - believe you can’t keep frozen food past it’s expiry date when in fact you can, although its quality will deteriorate. Finally 41 per cent believe it's dangerous to defrost certain types of food on the counter, when in reality but it should, ideally, be defrosted in the fridge to prevent it entering the danger zone of five to 63 degrees. The study also found that, as a nation, we get through 300 million frozen food items a week, from frozen fruit and veg to frozen fish. And six in 10 said there are certain foods they would prefer to buy frozen, including peas, fish fingers and fish fillets. It also emerged peas come out on top as the most regularly consumed frozen food, ahead of chips and even ice cream.

title: he too young full time
story: News"He is too young for full time education" Mum refuses to send son, 4, to school so can spend more time at homeStanley Hutchinson, 4, was due to start school in September but will spend time at home with his mum and younger brother insteadShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByJoanna LovellNeil Murphy09:39, 19 SEP 2018Updated11:11, 19 SEP 2018NewsEmma Hutchinson with her son Stanley"Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA mum has refused to send her four-year-old son to school this year because he is 'too young for full-time education.' Stanley Hutchinson was due to start school two weeks ago but is currently spending his days at home with mum, Emma, and his younger brother. Emma, 38, says she wants her son to enjoy days of 'fun and freedom' and 'playing in the wild', Hull Live reports . Stanley is a June baby and so is one of the youngest in the school year. He does not have any additional needs, but his parents believe it is in his best interests to start school next year, once he is five and at compulsory school age .  In her blog, Dirt, Diggers and Dinosaurs , his mum explains her reasons for holding him back by applying to defer his admission to school for a year. She starts by saying: We’ve done something that many of our friends and family will view as controversial. We have decided not to send Stanley to school this year. Instead, he will be starting next September when he is five. For the extra year he will be attending preschool part time, playing, bonding with his brothers, playing, exploring, enjoying days out, playing, growing and developing at his own pace. She then answers some of the questions she says she's been asked.  No, Stanley does not have any special educational needs. No, we haven’t ‘held him back’ because he was struggling at preschool. No, it’s not that we can’t bear to let him go, and I want to keep him a baby. No, we aren’t doing it for ourselves and not thinking about what’s best for him. No, we’ve not thrown our dummy out because he didn’t a place at our first choice of school this year... he did. No, we’ve not done what’s easiest for us.   As you can probably tell from the answers above, I’ve had a bit of an ear bashing by some which I hope is mostly fuelled by misinformation and misunderstanding, she says. Explaining her decision, she said: The plain fact is, he’s four. We’ve simply chosen not to send him to school early, we are sending him at school age which  you go back a generation was the absolute norm. I personally believe that in the UK all children start school too early and that we’d be better off following our European neighbours whose children start school at aged seven when they are emotionally and physically ready.  We were recently informed at a preschool parents evening that Stanley  would soon cope with starting school, as he’s really bright. This really hit home for me, a four year old shouldn’t have to cope with anything. Emma, from Hull, Yorkshire, who is expecting another baby, says she decided to write the blog to let other parents know it is possible to prevent your child from starting school at the age of four, as she believes it's not widely known. This year three set of parents have successfully applied to Hull City Council to defer their child's entry to school. Emma said: I’ve had two relative strangers - who I only know through ious kids clubs - tell me that they think it’s amazing, and one who asked me to email her the info so she could then look into it for her daughter. She had no idea that the option was available, which I think is a massive issue. Thanks to a change in DfE legislation, we not only have the choice whether to start his school journey prior to CSA or at CSA but also have the right to request admission into Reception class at CSA rather than Year One, ensuring that he will not lose a vital whole year of early education. I think an extra year of being a child with no responsibility or pressure can only be a good thing. When I read articles about phonics tests in Year one ages five and six and SATS at ages six and seven it makes me so sad. When did being a child become so target driven? Aren’t we told by midwives and health visitors that ‘they all learn at their own pace?' Why does this suddenly change when they enter the school system? The extra year at home will be an extra year of developing emotionally and at his own pace. An extra year of learning through play, exploration and love.  A controversial decision which is a big 'gamble' Emma said she 100 per cent believes she has made the right decision for Stanley, but admits there is a big gamble involved. She said: The BIG gamble in all of this and the only thing that regularly niggles at me is whether we will get offered our first choice school again in the next round of admissions. If we don’t, then will our offered school be happy to support a CSA Reception start, or will they be championing Year 1? The LEA and school would have to provide evidence that missing a whole year of education would be in his best interests. I guess we’ll just have to face any obstacles, and fight the battles as we get to them. However Emma signs the blog post off by saying as she sits there writing the post and watching Stanley performing a puppet show for his brother using three toy dinosaurs, she knows with all certainty that this is the best thing for her child.

story: NewsParents must pay £500 for daughter's bus pass her walk 'dangerous' three-mile journey to school as 0.021 miles outside areaMike North, 36, says he and his we Lucy, 37, were denied a free pass for 11-year-old Isabelle because they live within three miles of her schoolShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByAlex Grove06:59, 19 SEP 2018Updated07:02, 19 SEP 2018Newsthis.style.display='none'"/Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror/news/uk-news/video/girl-11-walk-hour-each-13270724,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-M3TH25P,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,bundledCss:false,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx/rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail/F/QVgi9PbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_/,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,bundledCss:false,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx/rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail/F/QVgi9PbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_/,nativeAppBanner:true""Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailAn angry dad says he was told to pay &pound500 a year for his young daughter's bus pass or let her face a dangerous one-hour trek to school. Mike North, 36, says he and his we Lucy, 37, were denied a free pass for 11-year-old Isabelle because they live within three miles of her school. But Mr North claims he carried out his own survey and found that his home in Swanland, East Yorkshire, is 3.021 miles from South Hunsley School in Melton.  East Riding Council wouldn't budge, however, and the Norths have been left scrambling to get their three children to two schools so Isabelle doesn't have to walk three miles along dangerous roads, Hull Live reports.   The council said it only awards free bus passes based on distances calculated by its own “geographic information system  mapping system,” which showed the distance to be less than three miles. Mr North said: “It’s an hour’s walk there and an hour’s walk back which the council are expecting her to do. We won’t let her do it because it’s a long way and she would have to set off early to get to school and for an 11-year-old it’s just not safe. “She would have to walk down dangerous roads, some of which have no street lights or footpaths, and in the winter it will be dark.”  Isabelle started at South Hunsley two weeks ago and since then, the Norths have had to juggle trying to take her and their six-year-old twins to their two schools in the morning and picking them up in the afternoons. When Isabelle has used the bus it has cost her &pound4 a day – a figure which the Norths say they cannot continue to afford to pay. Mr North says not having the free bus pass has caused his eldest child a great deal of upheaval during the first two weeks at her new school. He said: “It has been a bit stressful for her. She was already worried about going to secondary school and the situation with the bus pass has made things worse.  “A lot of her friends are on the bus and being driven to school by your parents isn’t the coolest thing, especially when you’re starting at a new school. “When I started secondary school I remember that everything was new and it was like a whole new world. Isabelle doesn’t need the added stress of not being able to get on the bus with her friends.” Mr North has been offered the chance to buy an annual bus pass for Isabelle for &pound520 and although he is livid at not being given a free one, he feels he may have to bite the bullet and pay the price. However, he believes the council is compromising his daughter’s safety by not giving her the free bus pass.

story: NewsTeenage girl is allergic to her own TEARS because of one-in-230-million people conditionLindsey Coubray, aged 19, suffers from aquagenic urticaria, which affects just one in 230 million people worldwide.Share&nbsp&nbspCommentsByLouie Smith16:52, 19 SEP 2018Updated16:53, 19 SEP 2018NewsLindsey Coubray has spoken about her rare condition "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA teenage girl has been diagnosed with an extremely rare condition which makes her allergic to her own tears. Lindsey Coubray, aged 19, suffers from aquagenic urticaria, which affects just one in 230 million people worldwide. She breaks out in severely itchy hives whenever she comes into contact with water - stopping her from showering or swimming. Lindsey suffers excruciating pain  she is caught out in a rain shower and the reaction is even triggered by her own sweat and tears. The office worker said: “People often wonder how I can be allergic to something that makes up 70 per cent of my body.  “There is often a sense of disbelief, followed by questioning how this is even possible. “Whenever I have a shower, as well as sneezing, I am covered from head to toe in an itchy rash which looks and feels like a nettle rash, my nose burns and my eyes become bloodshot and swollen. “Warm weather is a particular challenge because I get hot, sweat and then end up with an intensely itchy rash all over my back, arms, head and chest. “If I get caught out in the rain, my skin gets very itchy and feels like it’s burning.” Lindsey, who had always sneezed while washing herself, was diagnosed two years ago after her symptoms worsened.  She has to take strong antihistamines and asthma medication before taking a shower. She also relies on drinking milk because water leaves her feeling nauseous and creates mouth sores. Lindsey, of Wheathamsted, Herts., is so senstive that even humidity can leave her struggling to breathe. She said: “Sometimes,  it has just stopped raining and I go outside, I can find myself feeling breathless.”  Lindsey is hoping to raise awareness of the condition and has set up an Instagram account ‘aquagenic.urticaria’ to try and help other sufferers.

story: NewsMum realises £3 Primark face mask has gone horribly wrong when husband bursts out laughingShe was meant to look like Disney's Princess Jasmine - but ended up looking like a horror movie villainShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByHelen Le CaplainNicola OakleyHead of Audience10:41, 19 SEP 2018NewsLaura, 28, didn't realise how terrying the mask looked "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailFace masks are meant to be a relaxing treat at the end of a long day - but one couple had the fright of their lives when indulging in a DIY pamper night. Laura Weiser, 28, purchased a Disney princess face mask from Primark last week, planning a relaxation session. On Saturday, after an exhausting day redecorating the front room of her house with husband Alan, Laura decided to have a soak in the bath before heading to bed, wearing the &pound3 Princess Jasmine face mask. But when her husband clapped eyes on her he burst out laughing, prompting her to clamber out of bed and take a selfie to see what all the fuss was about. Laura, a full-time mum, was shocked when she realised she looked less Disney princess and more like Leatherface from 1974 horror film The Texas Chainsaw Massacre.  Laura, from Oxford, said: It looks beautul before you put it on, but when it's on it's a really scary-looking face - it's absolutely terrying. I knew as soon as my husband saw me that something was up, he was just sat next to me in bed in stitches. That's never a good sign. I remember thinking to myself 'it can't be that bad' so I got up and took a picture. But yes, it really was. It's quite an unusual look with big eyes printed on it, I've never had a sheet mask where the eyes are covered up before, I guess it's to give you the full effect. It reminded me of the character Leatherface from The Texas Chainsaw Massacre.  Self-professed Disney fan Laura who lives with Alan and their four children Bonnie, 10, Nigel, 8, Dennis, 5, and Lincolnr, 2, snapped up the cucumber sheet face mask from the Oxford branch of the chain a fortnight ago. When the mum-of-four opened the packaging to the 'A Whole New World' face mask she was thrilled to see the outline of Princess Jasmine's face sporting her signature cat-eye make-up, scarlet lips and gold earrings. However when the mask went on it distorted the hugely popular character's features leaving friends and family in stitches at her bizarre look. Pals posting on social media compared her to the murderous Leatherface - who wears masks made of his victims' skin. Laura said: My daughter Bonnie found it hilarious but I took it off after 15 minutes as I was worried about the younger kids walking in and seeing me,  they had they would have probably cried. It looked atrocious, it was the most bizarre thing ever, but a really good novelty. Alan looked over at me and burst out laughing. The mouth didn't line up, so it looked like I had two mouths and it was just really scary, but also funny.  I sent a picture to my mother-in-law and sister-in-law and they sent messages back with lots of laughing emojis. Laura said that although the face mask was the cause of a few laughs, she couldn't fault the quality of the product which left her skin feeling refreshed. Laura said: Despite looking so terrying, the product itself was amazing, I had lovely skin afterwards and my face was very moisturised.

story: NewsDistraught mother hands over newborn daughter to woman she met online for £34 in distressing CCTVBoth women have been arrested on child trafficking charges after the handover was caught on CCTV at an airportShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByKelly-Ann MillsWill Stewart12:25, 19 SEP 2018Newsthis.style.display='none'"/Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror/news/world-news/video/mother-hands-over-new-born-13271686,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-M3TH25P,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,bundledCss:false,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx/rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail/F/QVgi9PbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_/,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,bundledCss:false,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx/rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail/F/QVgi9PbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_/,nativeAppBanner:true""Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA distraught mum handed her nine-day-old daughter to a stranger she met online in exchange for &pound34, police say. CCTV, released by police, shows the deeply distressing last few moments 25-year-old Inna Petrova has with her tiny child, clutching her tightly, before she hands her over. The unemployed painter at one point can be seen turning her back on Natalia Zhdanova who has flown 1,970 miles from St Petersburg to Omsk collect the baby. But then Inna kisses her little one for the last time and hands over the child, who is cocooned in a bright pink wrap. Natalia then used a faked birth certicate - which listed the baby as hers - to show airport security before flying back to her home city with the child, police say.  Inna - who later said she was “hysterical” at giving away her child - is seen wiping tears from her eyes on the video, released by the Investigative Committee, which probes serious crimes in Russia. She now admits she was wrong and says she wishes she could wind back the clock. Ahead of the child's birth, Natalia had sent Inna a payment of 3,000 roubles - just &pound34. Natalia, a 43-year-old teacher, is said to have empty nest syndrome now her after her adult son left home, and wanted one last baby. She already bringing up another adopted daughter. Now both women have been formally detained as a criminal probe is launched under Russia’s child trafficking laws. They could each face up to ten years in jail.  Investigators say that Natalia posted an online advertisement saying: “Hi everyone! My husband and I would very much like to get a baby aged 0 to 3 months. All the documents for adoption are ready. Please send a private message for details. Girls, darlings, please help.” Inna - at the time pregnant after a short relationship with a man she met at a local cafe - replied: “Hello, I would like my daughter to be adopted. Please do so, I am not able to raise her, no chance”. She told police she lived with her mother and sister in a cramped apartment and they were furious when she became pregnant. They were adamant she should not keep the baby. Omsk prosecutor Vasily Gumenyuk said: “During our interrogation, the biological mother of the baby explained that she lived in a rented apartment with her mother and sister. “Both were strongly against the baby and put strong psychological pressure on the future mother.  “The young woman failed to get a job, and she was not married to the father of her baby. “He knew about her pregnancy but did not plan to support her. “She decided to give away the baby to the teacher from St Petersburg.” The baby deal would have remained secret but for Inna and her mother telling their landlady - who immediately informed police. Officers knocked on Natalie’s door in St Petersburg one week after the airport exchange. Inna said: “All the way through my pregnancy, my mother and sister were attacking me. “They wanted me to have an abortion. “My mother threatened me, saying ‘If you give birth, just don’t come back home, I won’t let you in!’” She said: “They told me a baby is not a toy.” “I posted in my social network that I needed help and Natalia Zhdanova replied.” She admitted she could have given the child up at her maternity hospital but chose not to and instead to hand the baby to Natalia who she had not previously met.  She was paid 3,000 roubles - sent in advance allegedly to cover the cost of nappies - but claimed Natalia also promised to help her and her family find jobs in St Petersburg. Asked about the moment she handed over the child, she said: “Of course it was hard. “I was in hysterics in the airport when it happened. “But Natalia’s  flight has already been announced, I had to give her my daughter so  could catch their plane. “My daughter was nine days old. I would have given her away earlier but we stayed in the hospital for a week, and then we lived at home for several days, but it was just impossible to be there because of constant scandals.” She said: “When the story became known, a friend of my mother said that she would have helped us.

story: NewsKate Middleton topless picture photographers lose appeal after snapping sunbathing royal in south of FranceCyril Moreau and Dominique Jacovides, of the Bestimage agency in Paris, have always insisted they are innocentShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByPeter Allen15:35, 19 SEP 2018Updated15:38, 19 SEP 2018NewsThe court result today was a victory for the Royal Family "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email Two French photographers who deny taking photographs of the Duchess of Cambridge sunbathing topless must still pay fines, an appeal court ruled today.  Cyril Moreau and Dominique Jacovides, of the Bestimage agency in Paris, were accused of snapping Catherine Middleton and her husband, Prince William, on a private holiday in the South of France.  The lensmen have always insisted they are innocent – pointing to a complete lack of evidence in a case that saw the Royal couple win &pound92,000 in compensation .  This is far more than is usually awarded in such privacy cases in France, leading to an appeal by French Closer Magazine, which published the snaps in 2012.  Moreau and Jacovides appealed sentences handed down in September 2017, but on Wednesday the Versailles Appeal Court, west of Paris, uphold them all. Prosecutor Marc Brisset-Foucault told the court: ‘There was an absolutely unacceptable breach, not only of the privacy and the private lives of these two iniduals, but also of the dignity of a woman.’ Long-lens cameras caught Kate solely wearing a pair of bikini bottoms, with William at one stage rubbing sun cream into his we’s skin.  At the time, the couple were relaxing at a Provence chateau owned by the Earl of Snowdon, the late Princess Margaret’s son.  The editor of Closer magazine , Laurence Piea, 52, and Ernest Mauria, the 72-year-old director of the Mondadori group which publishes it, were fined &pound42,000 each.  The photographers were also fined the equivalent of up to &pound8,500 each, after Prince William presented statements attacking the paparazzi.

Heart-warming footage has emerged of an elephant displaying 'human-like traits' while making sure her sleeping baby is still alive and well. The mum first extends her trunk tenderly over her son's chest before moving to check to see  he is breathing through its trunk. Elephants are known to show signs of emotions such as anger, joy and grief and are among of the most intelligent animals on the earth. This delicate moment between mother and son were filmed in Thailand. The species is under threat across the world, largely due to poaching for ivory. Large numbers of elephants were lost during the 20th century as they were killed for their tusks and as humans competed for resources.  Climate change is also playing a part in destroying the chances for elephant survival, as their environment will become drier and hotter. Leslie A. Temanson, a former programme director at Volunteer in Thailand with Friends for Asia, filmed the clip. He said, Moms are moms, no matter the species. story: NewsSouth Sudan Amnesty International report claims families have been burned alive and babies crushed to deathThe full scale of atrocities committed by soldiers and militia in South Sudan was today exposed in an investigation by Amnesty International.Share&nbsp&nbspCommentsByMirror01:20, 19 SEP 2018Updated03:08, 19 SEP 2018Newsthis.style.display='none'"/Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror/news/world-news/video/footage-shows-displaced-people-south-13270635,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-M3TH25P,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,bundledCss:false,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx/rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail/F/QVgi9PbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_/,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,bundledCss:false,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx/rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail/F/QVgi9PbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_/,nativeAppBanner:true""Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe full scale of atrocities committed by soldiers and militia in South Sudan was today exposed in an investigation by Amnesty International. Civilians described gang rapes on an industrial scale, toddlers being swung against tree trunks until they were dead and families barricaded in their homes to be burned alive. When a mother fled from one inferno carrying a small baby she was shot and the child crushed to death by a soldier, an eye-witness said. The testimony was gathered from 100 people who survived an offensive in Unity State, in the northern Greater Upper Nile region of the country, between April and July this year. Government troops are accused of giving free rein to youth militias, unleashing a wave of systematic slaughter. The epicentre of the violence was Mayendit and Leer counties, areas held by the opposition.  Witnesses described civilians being slaughtered in their villages. Some were burned alive in their tukuls - traditional mud huts which often have a thatched roof. A man believed to be over 90 had his throat slit. Nyaweke, a 20-year-old woman, said she saw soldiers shoot dead her father and kill a number of children in Thonyoor, in Leer There were seven men [soldiers] who collected the children and put them into a tukul and they set the tukul on fire. I could hear the screaming. They were four boys. One boy tried to come out and the soldiers closed the door on him. There were also five boys whom they hit against the tree, swinging them. They were two [or] three years old. They don’t want especially boys to live because they know they will grow up to become soldiers. In a separate incident in Rukway village, also in Leer, a couple and their two grandsons were burned alive in a house. Their daughter attempted to flee with her baby but she was shot and her child stamped to death. Even those who fled their villages had little chance of survival. Soldiers used amphibious vehicles to hunt those who had fled into swamps.  Nyalony, an elderly woman, told Amnesty she witnessed soldiers killing her husband and two other men: When the attack started, early in the morning while we were sleeping, my husband and I ran to the swamp together. Later in the morning, after the fighting was over, the soldiers came into the swamp looking for people, and sprayed the area where we were hiding with bullets. My husband was hit he cried out in pain. He was still alive, though, and the soldiers caught him, and then they shot him again and killed him. He was unarmed and wasn’t a fighter just a farmer.” Survivors faced unspeakable horror. Women and young girls said that they were abducted before being gang raped, sometimes for many weeks. Others were used as slaves to cook and clean for their captors. A 60-year-old man found his niece after she had been sexually assaulted by five men. She was just 13. My brother’s daughter was raped and she was going to die, he said. When they raped her, we came and found her and she was crying and bleeding … she couldn’t hide … she told me she was raped by five men. We could not carry her and she could not walk. There were also reports of sexual mutilation and castration.  Nyatap, who is around 32, gave a graphic account of her ordeal. Eight months pregnant, she was abducted with her five-year-old son and daughter, seven. There were 20 soldiers, she said. The other women who are not pregnant were raped. There was another lady... she was three months' pregnant and she miscarried. She was raped by 10 men. I saw it happen. They were just raping her under another tree. They put us in one compound.... there were other ladies... They would take turns raping them. Soldiers accused of carrying out the slaughter are also said to have looted and burned on a vast scale, making it virtually impossible for survivors who had fled to  to their homes. Amnesty claims that the situation was enabled by South Sudan's government failing to prosecute suspected war criminals for previous massacres in 2016. Four people had been identied but no action had been taken. Joan Nyanyuki, Amnesty International’s Regional Director for East Africa, said: “A key factor in this brutal offensive was the failure to bring to justice those responsible for previous waves of violence targeting civilians in the region. “Leer and Mayendit counties have been hard hit in the past, and yet the South Sudanese government continues to give suspected perpetrators free rein to commit fresh atrocities. The result has been catastrophic for civilians.” Amnesty has called for immediate end to all human rights abuses. Joanne Mariner, Amnesty International’s Senior Crisis Response Adviser, said: “It’s impossible to ignore the cruel reality –  the South Sudanese authorities had acted on our warnings back in 2016, this latest wave of violence against civilians in Leer and Mayendit might have been avoided. The only way to break this vicious cycle of violence is to end the impunity enjoyed by South Sudanese fighters on all sides. The government must ensure that civilians are protected and that those responsible for such heinous crimes are held to account.

title: csaba laszlo says fraser fyvie has all the right stuff
story: Dundee United manager Csaba Laszlo was delighted to welcome club captain Fraser Fyvie back to the fold on Saturday and believes he is just what they need to push on.The midfield man came off the bench on 73 minutes after recovering from a long-term knee injury and made a huge impact for the Terrors.With practically the last kick of the game Fyvie netted a terric half-volley to equalise after Morton had taken the lead through a Michael Tidser penalty on 11 minutes.It was not just the goal, but his overall play, which pleased Csaba.“I am happy to have him back, not just because he scored the goal, but he is a player who can create chances and shoot,” he said.“In the last 20 minutes he showed his experience and he knows what you have to do.“He comes on and in just 20 minutes he shoots three times. Two were very dangerous and the third was the goal.“Fraser is definitely a leader but we must be careful with him because he had two cruciate ligament problems so it has not been easy for him to handle this psychologically.”Ahead of Saturday’s trip to face bottom side Falkirk, Csaba has decisions to make in his midfield.After his dominant 20-minute display at Tannadice, Fyvie will be in contention to start and Csaba also revealed Sam Stanton is close.“It is good that he is making competition. Him and Sam Stanton must come back, hopefully, very quick. Maybe this week he will begin training,” he added.“He is also a creative midfielder who can score goals from the middle.“He scored a fantastic goal against Queen of the South.”

title: dundee united gaffer csaba laszlo blasts referee after spot kick call
story: Dundee United manager Csaba Laszlo has hit out at referee Colin Steven after he gave a controversial penalty against his side on Saturday.Steven pointed to the spot on 11 minutes when debutant Rachid Bouhenna was adjudged to have fouled Morton defender Gregor Buchanan in the box from a corner.Michael Tidser stepped up to give the ’Ton the lead in a Championship game which finished 1-1 thanks to substitute Fraser Fyvie’s last-minute equaliser.Although Csaba was pleased with the fight they showed to win a point, he was frustrated at the referee’s performance.“I am really proud of the boys because it was a really dficult game,” he said.“You get a penalty against you, and I don’t want to talk about the performance of the referee because it’s not my job, but I thought it was a foul for us at first.“I didn’t hear the whistle, then the referee shows for the penalty but I think, to be honest,  he gives this penalty then he has the chance to give 10 others for both sides.“It’s just my opinion and it is not all about the penalty. I don’t want to criticise the referee but, according to me, it was a very soft penalty.“I asked my players  there was contact there but they didn’t think it was one which you have to give.”Of United’s display, Csaba added: “I think for 90 minutes plus added time we played one-way football.“The boys tried hard and it’s not easy when the clock is ticking down and you still can’t score.“In the first-half we had two very good chances where we should score and in the second half we were pressing Morton.“They were, more or less, 11 behind the ball playing very deep and they tried to counter attack.“Sometimes you have these games where you have to suffer but we have to be more clinical, must be more clinical.“We can talk about the many mistakes but we have to play faster, more with the ball into feet and up front but I think on Saturday everybody showed spirit.”

title: new boy rachid bouhenna says dundee united have to work to win back supporters
story: Dundee United defender Rachid Bouhenna insists they must repay the fans for their support with a win at Falkirk on Saturday.The French-Algerian centre-back made his United debut in their disappointing 1-1 draw with Morton at Tannadice at the weekend.The Terrors now travel west for a crucial Championship tie after captain Fraser Fyvie, ing from a long-term injury off the bench, salvaged a point with a last-minute strike against Jonatan Johansson’s side – who took an early lead through a Michael Tidser penalty.And Bouhenna says they will do everything they can to pick up three points and get the Arabs back onside ahead of, what he insists is, a continued promotion push.“Of course for Dundee United the objective is to go to the top league, the Premiership, so we have to win these games at home and get results away,” he said.“Saturday we lost two points, we need to win the supporters back this weekend at Falkirk and I hope next year we will play in the top tier.“The fans were amazing, we need them for the rest of the season and I think they are behind us.“After the game I thought it was a good game but we had many chances to score and didn’t take them.“It’s good to come back to draw but for the next game we have to win  we want to stay near the top of the Championship.”Despite hauling down Gregor Buchanan for the penalty which Tidser converted to give the Ton the lead on 11 minutes, Bouhenna was pleased with his first run-out in tangerine.However, The 27-year-old was not happy with referee Colin Steven’s call to award the spot-kick after the tussle with Buchanan at a corner and Bouhenna expressed his surprise given the physical nature of Scottish football.He added: “It was an OK debut I think.“Only really the foul for the penalty – I can’t believe it.“I don’t think it was, he did not have the ball and we are in a duel but I don’t know why.“It was not just the penalty, it was every ball the referee whistle against us.“It is not like Algeria or France, for sure.“It is more physical but Morton was a very physical game – that is the big dference and I think we can play more football at home.“Away it will be very dficult, you saw in the last game at Alloa you can’t play because of a dficult pitch but at home we have to play more.“Next game it will be very dficult when we play against Falkirk, so we have to get used to this.”Bouhenna is still settling into le in Dundee and getting to grips with the language – not to mention the accent.However, he still feels at home after being welcomed by everyone at the club.Skipper Fyvie, in particular, impressed the big defender with his influence on the side when he entered the fray on 73 minutes.The 25-year-old changed the game and got the equaliser with a ferocious half volley in second-half stoppage time.“Fraser has the experience, when he come on to pitch he helped us.“He is good for us and I hope in the next game he can continue to help us  he is in the starting XI or comes on to the pitch.“I am enjoying being at Dundee United, I am feeling very good.“My team-mates and everybody at the club have been very nice, they feel like family and I am very happy with it.“With the manager and the team-mates it is very good but we have to keep going, keep working and think about the next game.”
